modules.description: This module provides hash computation and HMAC generation functionalities, supporting operations on byte-based data types like `Bytes.t`, `String.t`, and `Digestif.bigstring`, as well as lists and iterators. It enables incremental data processing, digest generation, and format conversions between hexadecimal, raw bytes, and pretty-printed representations, with options for secure, constant-time comparisons. Use cases include cryptographic integrity checks, secure message authentication, and flexible data serialization workflows.

Provides functions to generate and access precomputed tables of elliptic curve points, specifically multiples of the generator point for scalar multiplication. Works with multi-dimensional arrays of strings representing curve data. Used to initialize cryptographic tables required for efficient public key operations.

The module offers hash computation and HMAC generation, supporting operations on byte sequences, strings, and bigstrings, along with incremental updates and direct digest generation. It includes specialized functions for handling diverse data formats, constant-time comparisons, and hex/raw string conversions, suitable for secure data integrity checks and cryptographic authentication. Abstract types `ctx` and `t` likely manage internal state and structured data, enabling efficient processing of large or streaming inputs.

Provides functions to generate and access precomputed tables of elliptic curve points, specifically multiples of the generator point for efficient scalar multiplication. Works with multi-dimensional arrays of strings representing curve data. Used to embed critical cryptographic tables directly into compiled code for performance.

This module provides cryptographic operations for hash computation and HMAC generation, supporting incremental and direct processing of data in formats like bytes, strings, and bigstrings. It handles byte-based data types and includes utilities for converting between hexadecimal, raw strings, and HMAC digest representations, along with secure comparison functions. Abstract types `ctx` and `t` likely manage context and structured data for these operations, applicable in scenarios requiring data integrity verification or secure authentication.

Provides functions to generate and access precomputed tables of elliptic curve points, specifically multiples of the generator point for efficient scalar multiplication. Works with multi-dimensional arrays of strings representing curve data. Used to embed critical cryptographic tables directly into the compiled code for performance.

Encodes and decodes secret values as binary buffers, supporting optional compression. Generates ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key pairs with customizable random number generators, ensuring valid private keys. Performs key exchanges using a secret and a received public key, validating the input against elliptic curve constraints.

Combines hash, HMAC, and elliptic curve operations for cryptographic tasks, handling byte sequences, strings, and curve data structures. Supports incremental hashing, digest conversion, secure comparisons, and precomputed elliptic curve points for efficient scalar multiplication. Enables integrity checks, message authentication, and public key initialization. Examples include generating HMACs from raw data, converting digests to hex, and using precomputed points for elliptic curve operations.

Encodes and decodes secret values as binary buffers, supporting optional compression. Generates ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key pairs with customizable random number generators, ensuring valid private keys. Performs key exchanges using a secret and a received public key, validating the input against elliptic curve constraints.

Combines cryptographic hash and HMAC operations with elliptic curve precomputation, enabling secure message authentication and efficient public-key cryptography. It handles byte sequences, strings, and bigstrings with incremental processing, and provides precomputed elliptic curve points for fast scalar multiplication. Operations include digest generation, constant-time comparisons, and format conversions, alongside table-based optimizations for cryptographic protocols. Users can verify data integrity, generate secure signatures, and accelerate elliptic curve computations in performance-critical applications.

Encodes and decodes secret values as binary buffers, supporting optional compression. Generates ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key pairs with customizable random number generators, ensuring valid private keys. Performs key exchanges using a secret and a received public key, validating the input against elliptic curve constraints.

Computes hashes and HMACs with support for incremental data processing, offering operations on byte sequences and conversions between formats, while providing secure comparison and context management. Implements elliptic curve precomputation tables for efficient scalar multiplication, embedding curve data directly into compiled code. Users can verify data integrity through hash comparisons or accelerate cryptographic operations using precomputed points. Examples include generating HMACs for message authentication or optimizing elliptic curve-based key exchanges.

This module offers hash and HMAC generation capabilities, supporting incremental data processing and direct digest computation across byte-based data types like `Bytes.t`, `String.t`, and `Digestif.bigstring`. It includes utilities for format conversion (hex, raw bytes) and secure comparisons, enabling use cases such as data integrity checks and cryptographic authentication. Abstract types `ctx` and `t` likely manage state and structured data within these operations.

Provides functions to generate and access precomputed tables of generator point multiples for elliptic curve operations, using arrays of strings to store fixed data. Works with cryptographic curve data structures, specifically tailored for scalar multiplication. Used to embed essential lookup tables directly into compiled code for efficient elliptic curve computations.

Encodes and decodes secret values, generates and validates elliptic curve key pairs, and performs Diffie-Hellman key exchanges using the NIST P-256 curve. Supports hash and HMAC computations, incremental data processing, and precomputed elliptic curve points for optimized scalar multiplication. Users can generate secure HMACs for message authentication or accelerate key exchanges with precomputed tables. Operations include validating public keys, securely comparing hashes, and managing cryptographic contexts.

Encodes and decodes secret values, generates and validates elliptic curve key pairs, and performs secure key exchanges using the NIST P-384 curve. Combines hash, HMAC, and elliptic curve precomputation to enable message authentication, signature generation, and optimized scalar multiplication. Processes byte sequences and bigstrings with incremental support and constant-time operations for secure, efficient cryptographic workflows. Examples include generating ephemeral keys, verifying data integrity, and accelerating public-key operations in high-performance systems.

Handles elliptic curve cryptography using the NIST P-521 curve, combining key generation, exchange, and cryptographic operations. It manages secret values, public keys, and hash-based authentication, with support for binary encoding, HMAC, and secure comparisons. Operations include generating ephemeral key pairs, performing Diffie-Hellman exchanges, and using precomputed points for efficient scalar multiplication. Examples include deriving shared secrets, authenticating messages with HMAC, and converting cryptographic digests to hexadecimal format.

Generates and manipulates X25519 elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman keys, converting between secret keys and byte strings. It supports key pair generation with optional compression and performs shared secret calculations from a secret and a public key. The module handles encoding and decoding of keys according to SEC 1 standards, ensuring valid curve points during exchanges.

Encodes and decodes private and public keys from and to byte buffers, and derives a public key from a private key. Generates random key pairs and signs/verifies messages using Ed25519 digital signatures. Processes raw byte strings for cryptographic operations compliant with RFC 8032.

Encodes and decodes secret values as binary buffers, supporting optional compression. Generates ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key pairs with customizable random number generators, ensuring valid private keys. Performs key exchanges using a secret and a received public key, returning shared secrets or errors based on input validity.

Combines hash, HMAC, and elliptic curve operations, enabling secure data authentication and cryptographic key exchanges. It defines types for context management and structured data, along with functions for incremental hashing, secure comparisons, and precomputed elliptic curve tables. Users can verify data integrity through digest generation or accelerate elliptic curve computations with embedded lookup tables. Examples include generating HMACs for message authentication or using precomputed points for efficient scalar multiplication.

This module offers hash and HMAC generation functionalities, supporting incremental and direct computation of digests from byte-like data structures such as `Bytes.t`, `String.t`, and `Digestif.bigstring`. It includes utilities for format conversion, constant-time comparisons, and handling diverse input sources, enabling secure data authentication and integrity checks. Abstract types `ctx` and `t` likely manage stateful operations and structured data within these cryptographic workflows.

Provides functions to generate and access precomputed tables of generator point multiples for elliptic curve operations, using arrays of strings to store fixed data. Works with cryptographic curve data structures requiring hardcoded values for efficient scalar multiplication. Used to initialize essential lookup tables in mirage-crypto-ec during build time.

Provides AES, RSA, and elliptic curve operations with built-in protections against timing attacks, including AES-NI acceleration and RSA blinding. Works with byte sequences, keys, and cryptographic contexts for encryption, decryption, and key exchange. Used for securing network communications, generating authenticated messages, and implementing secure key derivation in MirageOS-based systems.

Offers hash and HMAC generation with support for incremental and direct computation across various data types, including byte sequences and bigstrings, while providing secure comparison and format conversion. Includes precomputed tables for elliptic curve operations, enabling efficient scalar multiplication through hardcoded generator point multiples. Users can authenticate data, verify integrity, and perform cryptographic operations like signing and key exchange. Examples include generating SHA-256 digests, creating HMACs with secret keys, and initializing elliptic curve parameters for public key algorithms.
